articles.headline: Citi Deals a New Deck of Credit Cards
articles.snippet: The bank is retiring some cards, adding new ones, raising annual fees and adding some perks.
articles.abstract: The bank is retiring some cards, adding new ones, raising annual fees and adding some perks.
articles.lead_paragraph: It can’t be much fun to be a credit card marketer right now.

articles.headline: Estate Tax Will Return Next Year, but Few Will Pay It
articles.snippet: The tax legislation passed by Congress means fewer wealthy people will have to pay an estate tax in 2011, but planning is still necessary.
articles.abstract: The tax legislation passed by Congress means fewer wealthy people will have to pay an estate tax in 2011, but planning is still necessary.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost no one will have to worry about paying the estate tax under the tax legislation just approved by Congress. By one estimate, from Alan Rothschild, the chairman of the American Bar Association’s real property, trust and estate law section, less than one-half of 1 percent of people who die in 2011 will be hit by the estate tax. In contrast, 10.5 percent paid the estate tax in 1977.

articles.headline: Best Buy Feels the Pressure of Rivals on the Web
articles.snippet: Best Buy is emphasizing the personal touch and service to buyers of consumer products, but its earnings and sales are declining.
articles.abstract: Best Buy is emphasizing the personal touch and service to buyers of consumer products, but its earnings and sales are declining.
articles.lead_paragraph: At barely 10 a.m., holiday shopping was in full swing at a Best Buy on the Upper West Side. A harried father searched for a new Xbox for his children. A personal assistant picked up video game accessories for her boss’s twins. One young woman fiddled with a coffeemaker, while another paid for a DVD player.

articles.headline: Explaining the Crisis With Dogma
articles.snippet: The Republican members of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission say the financial crisis was caused primarily by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
articles.abstract: The Republican members of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission say the financial crisis was caused primarily by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
articles.lead_paragraph: What was that about?

articles.headline: Santa via Cellphone: Shopping Online Without a Computer
articles.snippet: This holiday season, consumers are beginning to shop and make purchases on their mobile phones and tablet computers.
articles.abstract: This holiday season, consumers are beginning to shop and make purchases on their mobile phones and tablet computers.
articles.lead_paragraph: This holiday season, consumers are beginning to shop and make purchases on their mobile phones. The shift from buying presents in front of the computer at home or work to doing it during bus commutes or while standing in line at cafes is small, but, for the first time, noticeable and even significant.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Verne G. Kopytoff

articles.headline: Newly Built Ghost Towns Haunt Banks in Spain
articles.snippet: The wreckage of Spain’s once booming construction industry is everywhere, and much of it sits as bad debt on the books of Spain’s banks.
articles.abstract: The wreckage of Spain’s once booming construction industry is everywhere, and much of it sits as bad debt on the books of Spain’s banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: YEBES, Spain  It is a measure of Spain’s giddy construction excesses that 250 row houses carpet a hill near this tiny rural village about an hour by car outside of Madrid.
articles.byline: By Suzanne Daley and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: Republicans Prepare for Looming Budget Battle
articles.snippet: Republicans hailed their ability to derail a $1.2 trillion spending measure put forward by Senate Democrats.
articles.abstract: Republicans hailed their ability to derail a $1.2 trillion spending measure put forward by Senate Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The collapse of a government-wide spending package in the final days of this Congressional session sets up a politically charged fiscal showdown early next year, testing the determination of Republicans about to take over the House with promises to slash an array of domestic programs.

articles.headline: Senate Repeals Ban Against Openly Gay Military Personnel
articles.snippet: Eight Republicans joined Democrats to vote 65 to 31 to end the policy known as “don’t ask, don’t tell.”
articles.abstract: Eight Republicans joined Democrats to vote 65 to 31 to end the policy known as “don’t ask, don’t tell.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Saturday struck down the ban on gay men and lesbians serving openly in the military, bringing to a close a 17-year struggle over a policy that forced thousands of Americans from the ranks and caused others to keep secret their sexual orientation.

articles.headline: Opening the Bag of Mortgage Tricks
articles.snippet: A federal court case in Nevada shines a light on loan servicing methods.
articles.abstract: A federal court case in Nevada shines a light on loan servicing methods.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALL the revelations this year about dubious practices in the mortgage servicing arena  think robo-signers and forged signatures  have rightly raised borrowers’ fears that companies handling their loans may not be operating on the up and up.

articles.headline: Oprah’s Network Is Her Highest Hurdle
articles.snippet: Ms. Winfrey’s move from broadcast to cable is a transformative moment for the television business and the stakes couldn’t be higher.
articles.abstract: Ms. Winfrey’s move from broadcast to cable is a transformative moment for the television business and the stakes couldn’t be higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEFORE Oprah Winfrey jetted off this month to Washington for the Kennedy Center Honors, then to Sydney for overseas tapings of her talk show, she had a simple request for the security staff at her house near Los Angeles:

articles.headline: What’s a Quiet Guy Doing on Real Estate’s A-List?
articles.snippet: A recent deal by Brookfield Asset Management has placed it and its Canadian chief executive, Bruce Flatt, among America’s top investors.
articles.abstract: A recent deal by Brookfield Asset Management has placed it and its Canadian chief executive, Bruce Flatt, among America’s top investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN General Growth Properties buckled under a mountain of debt and filed for bankruptcy last year, deal watchers assumed that Simon Properties, the nation’s largest mall owner, would swoop in and buy it. So many people were stunned when Brookfield Asset Management, a lesser-known company that is based in Toronto, beat out Simon last May and snagged a major ownership stake.

articles.headline: Zimbabwe Health Care, Paid With Peanuts
articles.snippet: For many rural people, cash is so scarce that the 85-bed Chidamoyo Christian Hospital allows bartering.
articles.abstract: For many rural people, cash is so scarce that the 85-bed Chidamoyo Christian Hospital allows bartering.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHIDAMOYO, Zimbabwe  People lined up on the veranda of the American mission hospital here from miles around to barter for doctor visits and medicines, clutching scrawny chickens, squirming goats and buckets of maize. But mostly, they arrived with sacks of peanuts on their heads.

articles.headline: Justices Offer Receptive Ear to Business Interests
articles.snippet: The percentage of business cases on the Supreme Court docket has grown, as has the percentage won by business interests.
articles.abstract: The percentage of business cases on the Supreme Court docket has grown, as has the percentage won by business interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Almost 40 years ago, a Virginia lawyer named Lewis F. Powell Jr. warned that the nation’s free enterprise system was under attack. He urged the U.S. Chamber of Commerce to assemble “a highly competent staff of lawyers” and retain outside counsel “of national standing and reputation” to appear before the Supreme Court and advance the interests of American business.

articles.headline: New Online-Date Detectives Can Unmask Mr. or Ms. Wrong
articles.snippet: Never mind whether your date is smart or good-looking. How do you know you aren’t flirting with a felon?
articles.abstract: Never mind whether your date is smart or good-looking. How do you know you aren’t flirting with a felon?
articles.lead_paragraph: Never mind whether your date is smart or good-looking. How do you know you aren’t flirting with a felon?

articles.headline: Politics in Iraq Casts Doubt on a U.S. Presence After 2011
articles.snippet: As contingency planning for any lasting American military mission has continued, the political landscape in both countries has made it more possible that the 2011 withdrawal could truly be total.
articles.abstract: As contingency planning for any lasting American military mission has continued, the political landscape in both countries has made it more possible that the 2011 withdrawal could truly be total.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Steven Lee Myers, Thom Shanker and Jack Healy and written by Mr. Myers.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers, Thom Shanker and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Democrats Scramble to Save Votes to Ratify Nuclear Pact
articles.snippet: The top two Senate Republicans vowed to vote against President Obama’s treaty with Russia as the bipartisan spirit of last week’s tax deal devolved.
articles.abstract: The top two Senate Republicans vowed to vote against President Obama’s treaty with Russia as the bipartisan spirit of last week’s tax deal devolved.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top two Senate Republicans declared Sunday that they would vote against President Obama’s nuclear treaty with Russia as the bipartisan spirit of last week’s tax-cut deal devolved into a sharp battle over national security in the waning days of the session.

articles.headline: Google TV Faces Delays Amid Poor Reviews
articles.snippet: Google is planning revisions and has asked TV makers to delay introductions, catching some off guard.
articles.abstract: Google is planning revisions and has asked TV makers to delay introductions, catching some off guard.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google TV has just enacted its first programming cancellation.
articles.byline: By Ashlee Vance and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Weighing Costs, Companies Favor Temporary Help
articles.snippet: There is concern that temporary employees will become a more entrenched part of the work force.
articles.abstract: There is concern that temporary employees will become a more entrenched part of the work force.
articles.lead_paragraph: Temporary workers are starting to look, well, not so temporary.

articles.headline: A Hollywood Brawl: How Soon Is Too Soon for Video on Demand?
articles.snippet: A smattering of specialty films are going to video on demand before a run in theaters. But is that applicable to big commercial releases?
articles.abstract: A smattering of specialty films are going to video on demand before a run in theaters. But is that applicable to big commercial releases?
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Perhaps the biggest fight on Hollywood’s horizon involves where and when consumers can watch movies.

articles.headline: Afghan War Just a Slice of U.S. Coverage
articles.snippet: The war has accounted for just 4 percent of the nation’s news coverage in major outlets this year, and covering it has been a complex proposition.
articles.abstract: The war has accounted for just 4 percent of the nation’s news coverage in major outlets this year, and covering it has been a complex proposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Obama administration conducted an Afghanistan-Pakistan strategy review this month, the news media did too, and the coverage came peppered with question marks.

articles.headline: Backing ‘Don’t Ask’ Repeal, With Reservations
articles.snippet: Interviews with about two dozen Marines revealed most did not object to gays serving openly but said it could be a problem in combat units.
articles.abstract: Interviews with about two dozen Marines revealed most did not object to gays serving openly but said it could be a problem in combat units.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, N.C.  Pfc. Daniel Carias, a Bronx native who is just weeks from graduating from Marine Corps infantry training at Camp Geiger near here, says he has known plenty of gay men since high school and feels completely comfortable around them.

articles.headline: This Bonus Season on Wall Street, Many See Zeros
articles.snippet: Traders, bankers and brokers face a bonus of nothing, and if their salaries have doubled, that is little consolation.
articles.abstract: Traders, bankers and brokers face a bonus of nothing, and if their salaries have doubled, that is little consolation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bonus season is fast approaching on Wall Street, but this year the talk does not center just on multimillion-dollar paydays. It’s about a new club that no one wants to join: the Zeros.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Online Stores Start to Wean Shoppers Off Sales
articles.snippet: Online retailers are offering fewer sales this holiday season but are reaping plenty of revenue. The discounts that are available are strategic and narrow.
articles.abstract: Online retailers are offering fewer sales this holiday season but are reaping plenty of revenue. The discounts that are available are strategic and narrow.
articles.lead_paragraph: This holiday season, online sales are zooming, even as online retailers offer fewer discounts and turn picky about who shops at their sites.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: A Lesson for Wall St. About Failure
articles.snippet: “The Company Men” manages to use a bunch of rich guys losing their jobs to reach a fundamental question of this economic age.
articles.abstract: “The Company Men” manages to use a bunch of rich guys losing their jobs to reach a fundamental question of this economic age.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s awards season again, and critics and the academy members are deciding on their top film picks of the year. But in many corners of the business community, the issue is already settled: “Waiting for ‘Superman’ ” is the year’s must-see film.
